dt.t: Thirty years have passed since a vaccine wiped out polio, but some of those who conquered the {wi}debilitating{/wi} disease as children are now experiencing symptoms that seem all too familiar.
Several of these drugs are now in clinical testing to determine whether they can reduce or eliminate the {wi}debilitating{/wi} nausea suffered by cancer patients on chemotherapy.

utxt.t: {wi}Debilitatingly{/wi} asthmatic as a child, Scarfe developed his talent while amusing himself and acquired the cynicism for authority that empowers his … drawings and sculpture during many frightening encounters with medical incompetence.

pt: {sc}weaken{/sc} {sc}enfeeble{/sc} {sc}debilitate{/sc} {sc}undermine{/sc} {sc}sap{/sc} {sc}cripple{/sc} {sc}disable{/sc} mean to lose or cause to lose strength or vigor. {sc}weaken{/sc} may imply loss of physical strength, health, soundness, or stability or of quality, intensity, or effective power.

pt.t: a disease that {it}weakens{/it} the body's defenses

pt: {sc}enfeeble{/sc} implies a condition of marked weakness and helplessness.
{sc}debilitate{/sc} suggests a less marked or more temporary impairment of strength or vitality.
{sc}undermine{/sc} and {sc}sap{/sc} suggest a weakening by something working surreptitiously and insidiously.

pt.t: drugs had {it}sapped{/it} his ability to think

pt: {sc}cripple{/sc} implies causing a serious loss of functioning power through damaging or removing an essential part or element.
{sc}disable{/sc} suggests bringing about impairment or limitation in a physical or mental ability.

pt.t: {it}disabled{/it} by an injury sustained at work

et: Latin {it}debilitatus{/it}, past participle of {it}debilitare{/it} to weaken, from {it}debilis{/it} weak
